Cool...doubt I'll ever use it though, because I think
the doclets are evil ;)  But I might dl it just to
play around with it.

(pulls out a huge sword and starts swinging wildly)

DIE, JAVADOC, DIE!!! ;)

-Eric


--- Robert Watkins <robertdw@...> wrote:
> I'm announcing the immediate availability of the
> first 'alpha' release
> of JUnitDoclet.
> 
> You can find it at
> http://www.sourceforge.net/projects/junitdoclet/ (in
> the 'Files' section).
> 
> JUnitDoclet is a XDoclet-based tool to manage the
> creation of JUnit test
> suites. For those not familiar with XDoclet, it is a
> tool that lets you
> generate files based on javadoc tags. For example,
> with JUnitDoclet, you
> simply put in a javadoc tag like this:
> 
> /**
>  * @junit:test suite="TestSuiteOne"
>  */
> public class XyzTest extends
> junit.framework.TestCase {
> ...
> 
> This will automatically put the test XyzTest into a
> suite called
> TestSuiteOne.
> 
> Not everybody uses test suites to organise their
> test cases, and one of
> the reasons is that it's a pain. JUnitDoclet makes
> it a lot easier. :)
> 
> This initial release works (I use it on my own
> projects), but is not
> extensively documented... that's in the works. I
> just thought I would
> make it available now for any interested parties.
> 
> If you have any questions, there is a mailing list
> set up at the
> sourceforge project as well.
> 
> Robert.
> 
> -- 
>                "Software is too expensive to build
> cheaply"
>   Robert Watkins                          email:
> robertdw@...
> 
>
